Object Oriented Interface¶

class oopinterface.BarotropicField(xlon, ylat, pv_field, area=None, dphi=None, n_partitions=None, planet_radius=6378000.0)[source]¶

An object that deals with barotropic (2D) wind and/or PV fields

Parameters:
  • xlon (sequence of array_like) – Longitude array in degree with dimension nlon.
  • ylat (sequence of array_like) – Latitutde array in degree, monotonically increasing with dimension nlat
  • area (sequence of array_like) – Differential area at each lon-lat grid points with dimension (nlat,nlon). If ‘area=None’: it will be initiated as area of uniform grid (in degree) on a spherical surface.
  • dphi (sequence of array_like) – Differential length element along the lat grid with dimension nlat.
  • pv_field (sequence of array_like) – Absolute vorticity field with dimension [nlat x nlon]. If ‘pv_field=None’: pv_field is expected to be computed with u,v,t field.
Returns:

an instance of the object BarotropicField
Example: 
>>> barofield1 = BarotropicField(xlon, ylat, pv_field=abs_vorticity)
equivalent_latitudes()[source]¶

Compute equivalent latitude with the pv_field stored in the object.

Returns:an numpy array with dimension (nlat) of equivalent latitude array.
Example: 
>>> barofield1 = BarotropicField(xlon, ylat, pv_field=abs_vorticity)
>>> eqv_lat = barofield1.equivalent_latitudes()
lwa()[source]¶

Compute the finite-amplitude local wave activity based on the equivalent_latitudes and the pv_field stored in the object.

Returns:an 2-D numpy array with dimension (nlat,nlon) of local wave activity values.
Example: 
>>> barofield1 = BarotropicField(xlon, ylat, pv_field=abs_vorticity)
>>> eqv_lat = barofield1.equivalent_latitudes() # This line is optional
>>> lwa = barofield1.lwa()
class oopinterface.QGField(xlon, ylat, zlev, u_field, v_field=None, t_field=None, qgpv_field=None, area=None, dphi=None, n_partitions=None, rkappa=0.2858565737051793, planet_radius=6378000.0, scale_height=7000.0)[source]¶

An object that deals with barotropic (2D) wind and/or PV fields

Parameters:
  • xlon (sequence of array_like) – Longitude array in degree with dimension (nlon).
  • ylat (sequence of array_like) – Latitutde array in degree, monotonically increasing with dimension (nlat)
  • zlev (sequence of array_like) – Pseudoheight array in meters, monotonically increasing with dimension (nlev)
  • u_field (sequence of array_like) – Zonal wind field in meters, with dimension (nlev,*nlat*,*nlon*).
  • v_field (sequence of array_like) – Meridional wind field in meters, with dimension (nlev,*nlat*,*nlon*).
  • t_field (sequence of array_like) – Temperature field in Kelvin, with dimension (nlev,*nlat*,*nlon*).
  • qgpv_field (sequence of array_like) – Quasi-geostrophic potential vorticity field in 1/second, with dimension (nlev,*nlat*,*nlon*). If u_field, v_field and t_field are input, qgpv_field can be using the method compute_qgpv.
  • area (sequence of array_like) – Differential area at each lon-lat grid points with dimension (nlat,*nlon*). If ‘area=None’: it will be initiated as area of uniform grid (in degree) on a spherical surface.
  • dphi (sequence of array_like) – Differential length element along the lat grid with dimension (nlat).
  • pv_field (sequence of array_like) – Absolute vorticity field with dimension [nlat x nlon]. If ‘pv_field=None’: pv_field is expected to be computed with u,v,t field.
Returns:

an instance of the object BarotropicField
Example: 
>>> qgfield1 = QGField(xlon, ylat, np.array([240.]), u, qgpv_field=QGPV)
equivalent_latitudes(domain_size='half_globe')[source]¶

Compute equivalent latitude with the pv_field stored in the object.

Parameters:domain_size (string) – domain of grids to be used to compute equivalent latitude. It can he ‘half_globe’ or ‘full_globe’.
Returns:an numpy array with dimension (nlev,*nlat*) of equivalent latitude array.
Example: 
>>> qgfield1 = QGField(xlon, ylat, np.array([240.]), u, qgpv_field=QGPV)
>>> qgfield_eqvlat = qgfield1.equivalent_latitudes(domain_size='half_globe')
lwa()[source]¶

Compute the finite-amplitude local wave activity on each pseudoheight layer based on the equivalent_latitudes and the qgpv_field stored in the object.

Returns:an 3-D numpy array with dimension (nlev,*nlat*,*nlon*) of local wave activity values.
Example: 
>>> qgfield = QGField(xlon, ylat, np.array([240.]), u, qgpv_field=QGPV)
>>> qgfield_lwa = qgfield.lwa()
